text:
Delicious! These were cooked perfectly. I used 6 bl/sl thighs, but kept the sauce ingredients the same. After the thighs were cooked, I took them out of the slow cooker and stirred in a little cornstarch slurry to thicken the sauce, which worked out great. Served over Jasmine rice and with a side of 'garlic broccoli' also from this site. The family cleaned their plates, so that makes this a definite keeper~YUM! Thanks for sharing. :)

Very easy and tasty.  I thickened the sauce with cornstarch.  I was short on time so I set my crock pot on high and it was done in 2 and a half hours.  Just for personal taste I added pineapple chunks, bell pepper and onion during the last 30 minutes.

text:
My whole family Loved this recipe, even my ultra-picky little boy! It was super easy, was made with ingredients I always have on hand, and it tasted GREAT with no adjustments necessary to the recipe! I used 8 chicken thighs & also 9 chicken tenders so I could free up space in the freezer and there was still Plenty of sauce! I put the chicken in a dish when it was done, strained the sauce into a saucepan, skimmed off the fat with a ladle & heated the strained  sauce with some cornstarch to thicken, and then poured the sauce over the chicken. I served it with brown rice & asparagus--Yum!!! Thank you for the great recipe! It will definitely be a keeper in our house!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this exactly as written ( I do use low sodium soy sauce even though the recipe doesn't specify), and for such minimal ingredients and effort, it is surprisingly very good as is.  Serve over rice or noodles with a veg. or salad on the side and it is a flavorful and very easy meal.  If you have a couple more minutes to spare on prep, and a few more ingredients in your pantry - I find this makes it even better- but just as easy:  Prepare as directed (I find you can use up to 6 thighs and still have plenty of sauce, and I use skinless thighs that still have the bone.) Add one - or more - or all- of the following to the sauce before pouring over chicken:  1 small onion chopped, 1 tsp. ground ginger, 1/4 to 1/2 tsp. red pepper flakes.  When done, if you happen to have any, add some fresh chopped green onion or scallions or parsley on top just before serving.  Some sesame seeds would also be a nice garnish.  But,,,,again, for such a simple recipe it is perfectly acceptable as is.

text:
My husband loved this chicken! So did I. Nice delicious thick sticky glaze on the moist chicken. I served it with rice pilaf with broccoli bits & slivered carrots & sliced almonds, & green salads as side dishes. Because of Asian type flavor, the only additions I made to this already perfect recipe were I drizzled a scant teaspoon of sesame oil over top and sprinkled about a half tablespoon of toasted sesame seeds over the top too about the last hour in the slow cooker & the seeds made it look really pretty & appealing & added a slight nice crunch.
Thanks for the easy & delicious dinner idea & recipe!

text:
Well i followed recipe, and all the comments advice. I used 9 thighs with skin and bone bc that what was in my freezer. I did honey soy sauce and ketchup. I put the garlic but used minced bc i didnt have fresh. I also added 1/2 cup sweet baby rays bbq and 1/4 cup brown sugar. And i also added red pepper flakes. (Thanks to suggestions of others)Cooked as recipe states...maybe a lil less time wasnt exactly timing it. Prob 4.5hrs. I then took thighs placed in baking pan. And the remaining liquid in pan i put in saucepan with cornstarch to thicken it up. I poured a lil over each thigh. Baked 15 or 20min on 400 degrees. It looked exactly like the picture. It was not too salty. The meat fell off bone. Served over white rice with seasoned and roasted brussel sprouts which i all cooked same time as the chicken in oven. So everything was done at same time. And it was very good. Its not like an award-winning chicken dish but it was packed with flavor, relatively healthy, super easy to make, other than slow cooker time it was quick to make. I will def make again. My boyfriend rates the chicken an 8 out of 10. So for a quick wed night meal ill take it and def make again!

text:
Fist I want to thank everybody for for writing reviews. Very helpful! I bought a tray of chicken thighs and wasn't sure how many to put in the crock pot (I have a large crock pot). I made the sauce and it was A LOT OF SAUCE! So I put all of the thighs I had, 12 total small thighs with bones and skin on. I like to cook with skin on because I feel that chicken is more juicy this way. I also made some changes to the sauce. I used low sodium soy sauce and substituted ketchup with BBQ sauce. A lot of people commented that ketchup flavor was too strong. I used 5 large garlic cloves and 1/3 cup of honey and 1 ts of dried basil. I cooked on low for 4-4.5 hours. My husband loved it and I will definitely make it again.

text:
Good starter, but needs a little "oomph". Sauce was okay, but thin, so I thickened it on the stove with cornstarch before pouring it over the chicken. I used 8 thighs instead of 4, but kept the sauce ratio the same. Thighs were tender and juicy. Second time I made it, I mixed into the sauce 1 1/2 tsp. cornstarch, 1 tsp. ground ginger, and about 1/4 tsp. cayenne pepper. The sauce was better, and thickened nicely in the slow-cooker. Might try crushed red peppers in it next time.

text:
This was really great! It was so easy to make, and I literally only had to purchase the chicken because I had everything else in the pantry. Sometimes I find that slow-cooker sauces with a lot of soy make the chicken overly salty, but that was not the case here. I served it with brown rice, and I threw some onions and carrots into the slow cooker for an additional side dish. I'd recommend doubling the recipe, or at least doubling the chicken amount--this went really fast, and I'd have loved some leftovers to eat for lunch. I will definitely make this again!

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Mine was definitely cooked enough at 5 1/2 hours on low. Tasty sauce; I would call it a sweet and tangy barbecue than leans more "tomato-ey" than most, but the basil gives it more complexity than that.  Easy to put together. The sauce   I almost always have to double the sauce in most recipes, because I like a ton of extra for my rice, pasta, etc.  But this had plenty of sauce on its own!!  Although it didn't REALLY need it, the sauce was even better when I took the advice of other reviewers about adding the slurry of cornstarch.  (I'm sure many know this trick.  But for those who don't, to avoid the cornstarch just curdling up in the warm sauce, you put about 1 tablespoons of corn starch in approximately 1/2 cup of water and whisk well.  Then adding a small amount at a time of the hot sauce to the cold mixture.  When mixture is more warm than cold, you then add it into the sauce.  You could increase the thickening effect even more by moving the sauce to a pan and bringing it to a boil.)  I used low-sodium soy-sauce.  It was great over brown rice.

text:
This turned out just beautiful! So moist and tasty. The reason I only gave it 4 stars is that I wanted to point out that it doesn't need to cook for the stated 6 hours. After 5 hours, I started to get just a whiff of burning, so I checked it and realized it was perfectly well done. I turned it off then and it was great. But had it gone for the 6 hours I'm sure it would have been burnt. I hate to use this rating to say this, but I really wish that cooks would rate the recipe AS IT IS, instead of as they adjusted it. Some cooks give a 5-star rating, but then go on to say the recipe as written was really bad. However with their adjustments it became a 5-star recipe. That confuses people who are looking for a recipe that is top-notch. OK, end of my ranting.

text:
At first when I went by the recipe, I wasn't really happy with the taste of the sauce, so went back and read some of the reviews on the dish and came up with my additions to make it to my liking.  I added some brown sugar which was suggested and that happened to help with the taste.  I used 6 chicken thighs and cooked them 4 hours.  In the last hour, I added sliced onion, green and red peppers and it ended up becoming a delicious recipe.  I did increase the sauce by a 1/3 and had way more sauce than I needed which I will use amounts recommended next time.  I served it over brown rice.  So this is my take on this dish.

region:

country:
None
text:
As a college student during summer, I don't have a lot of time to prepare fancy meals every night. This recipe was an excellent opportunity to rid the freezer of some chicken thighs as well. 

Several alterations however; I used a 1/2 cup of red wine leftover from a previous dish (it makes everything better), and instead substituted a small packet of soy sauce and added a half an onion. Before starting the crock pot, I put a small line of honey along the top of each thigh. Afterwards, a small flour roux made an unforgettable sauce that makes this dish blossom with flavor and kept it from being too dry. The only change I would make is to up the garlic to 5 good size cloves, as three didn't get me that divine subdermal layer that I crave.

Overall a darn good recipe to add to your arsenal, though I think each chef will want to play around to give it a personal touch.

text:
I followed the recipe exactly. The resulting chicken looked fairly unappetizing compared to the pictures on here, but looks aren't the end of the world.

The tops of the chicken that were not submerged in the sauce got overcooked, dry, and tough. I cut those parts out, but the rest of the chicken tasted bitter. Girlfriend ate one forkful and wouldn't eat any more. I ate about half the thighs, but only in an effort to not waste food. I eventually gave up and tossed the rest.

I don't understand how so many people could consider this a 4 or 5 star recipe, even with some of the modifications they made. I wonder if I made a colossal mistake somewhere, but it's such a simple recipe that I don't know how I could have done that.

Fantastic meal, it worked out great..For anyone avoiding soy, there is an alternative for soy sauce that works fantastic, it is gluten free and soy free, it is called Coconut aminos, and no you can't taste the coconut, I have used it quite often, and is the best alternative to soy sauce, less sodium and no soy :-)
I did cut back on the amount of soy (coconut amino's, I think it would have been too salty otherwise..I used 1/4 cup not a half cup)

I also sprinkled a little sesame seed on top just to finish it off, and served with rice and carrots on the side...

text:
I'm not a fan of chicken thighs or honey garlic sauce but this recipe looked so easy I decided to make this one for those in the house that do.  To my amazement - even I loved this!  It doesn't get much easier than this recipe (I made it as written except for adding extra garlic and about a teaspoon of chilis in oil to the sauce mix.  I hesitated on the basil, didn't seem to fit with the other flavours, but decided I should try it at least once and I'm glad I did).  I was impressed that the chicken actually comes out looking just like the recipe picture (I usually find crock pot meals aren't very aesthetically pleasing).  I served it with steamed broccoli in garlic butter and basmati rice.  We used the sauce on our rice (I noticed many reviewers thickened the sauce but I didn't bother and we were all happy with it exactly as it came out of the crock pot).  This will definitely be going into my regular rotation.  Using ingredients that are always on hand, it turns low cost thighs into an excellent meal that I can have completely ready in under 20 minutes in the kitchen.

userID:

Display Name:
SHRLYANN
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We liked this very much.  I especially liked the simplicity of this recipe.  But my chicken was half frozen, bone-in thighs and my time limited for slow cooking.   I  did it anyway.  Took about 15 minutes to have it in the slow cooker and that included the partial thawing time for the chicken in the microwave.  Using my high setting on the slow cooker, the dish was done in 2 hours and 30 minutes.  Chicken was tender and had great flavor.  I think I only made a couple of changes/additions:  using low sodium soy sauce and adding a half tsp. of crushed red pepper.  (I might add more red pepper next time as it wasn't at all spicy.)   I  served it with Basmati rice and a bag of vegetables steamed in the microwave.   Our granddaughter and her friend were very complimentary and my husband said the recipe is definitely a keeper.   So I will be making it again. Thanks for such a simple recipe.  UPDATE:  Made this again tonight but used country style pork ribs instead of chicken.  I did thaw the ribs, added 1 tsp. crushed red pepper and slow cooked on low for 6 hours.  The meat was tender without falling apart.  Served with last night's Basmati rice and glazed carrots.  My husband said he liked this sauce with the pork better and it was a totally different flavor.  So simple and versatile, truly a keeper.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1305013.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was super good! We dont like basil so left that out. And I used chicken legs since thats all I had. Put in crock pot for 5 hours exactly but put it together and let it sit in the fridge all morning first :) 
Only thing I did differently is the same as other reviewers and after the 5 hours of cooking I took the legs out, put on foil lined pan (about an inch deep), then I took the sauce out and put in pan and thickened with cornstach. I took a brush and basted the legs with the glaze and put in oven for a few minutes. then pulled out, basted again with the brush and put on broil for 2 minutes to get it nice and sticky and a bit 'crunchy' skin.
This was so good my husband said it was some of the best chicken he'd ever had. Served over white rice using the sauce spooned over it of course, with green beans. The ONLY reason this didnt get 5 stars from me is because im 7 months pregnant, it didnt fill me up for long, woke up starving the next morning, its most deff. a 'healthy low fat' dinner :) the chicken just falls off!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Cooked this tonight using low-sodium soy sauce and it came out great.  I think if we'd used regular soy sauce, it would have been too salty, so very glad we used this. The chicken wasn't thawing fast enough, so it was still partly frozen when I put the thighs in the crock pot.  Cooked on low for 3 hours and it was fine - meat was proper internal temp and was falling apart with a fork.  Then again, things always seem to cook fast in ours, which is a large crock pot brand "smart pot" with a heavy removable ceramic dish - 6 quarts i think.  

Some say the glaze was thick and sticky but ours was the consistency of water.  But that was fine - we just ladled some over the white rice we served the chicken on, and everything was great.  will definitely be using this recipe again!

text:
I always use low sodium kikkoman soy sauce so I can control how much salt I want in a dish and it was a great way to go in this as well! Put frozen boneless skinless chicken thighs in with the sauce ingredients and it was perfect when I got home 6 hours later! was generous with the garlic and stingy with the salt and loved the final project! Some jasmine rice and steamed broccoli all drizzled with sauce that I thickened a little with cornstarch on the stove top made the meal. a winner for sure! thanks for sharing!

Display Name:
jacswho919

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I didn't have basil and I used 8 chicken thighs and 5 cloves of garlic instead. I also ended up just cooking it for 5 hours instead of the 6. I think 6 would have been too long for my slow cooker and thighs because they were already a bit on the dry side. I would try 4.5 hours next time. 

Another thing is that it does taste borderline too salty. The flavours were strong in general, but I did find myself needing to mix the chicken and sauce with plain rice to make it more palatable. I think I would go with less soy sauce next time, maybe 1/3 of a cup. 

The sauce was the consistency of water. Next time, I would make less of it and add some corn starch to thicken it up. 

All in all, it was pretty easy, I think it's just a matter of tweaking it to my taste. I would make this again with adjustments.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The entire family loved it. I used 8 chicken thighs with skin. I made a few changes because my family prefers a more crispy skin so I browned the chicken in butter in a skillet first. To spice up the sauce a bit, I added 1/4 cup of sweet red chili. When the dish was finished cooking in the crockpot, I removed the chicken and placed in the broiler for 5-10 minutes to crisp the skin again. While the chicken was in the broiler, I thickened the sauce by returning it to the heat and adding corn starch.  It came out delicious. Three generations gave 2 thumbs up in the household, which is very hard to do.

Note to the critical reviews: As with most recipes, you have to thicken the sauce with cornstarch in order to get the full flavor.

text:
I thought this was really tasty! I used chicken breasts because that was all I had on hand. I  also didn't have time to use my slow cooker so I turned in the oven to 400¬∞, halved 3 large chicken breasts, sprayed my baking dish lightly with cooking spray, laid the chicken breasts evenly on the baking dish,   covered with foil and baked it for 40 minutes. I let the chicken rest for 10 minutes covered and it was very tender! I did what other reviewers suggested and lightly thickened the sauce with cornstarch. I served the chicken and sauce on brown rice with steamed broccoli on the side and it was yummy. I just wish I made a double batch of sauce, it tastes kind of like a teriyaki sauce and tasted awesome on rice. My family ate it all up and was scraping the dish for more sauce

text:
I tripled the amount of chicken and sauce, and ended up with way too much sauce.  Next time, I would use double the amount of sauce, and even that might be too much.  I had hoped for a rich flavorful sauce, but like some other reviewers, I was unimpressed with the flavor of the finished sauce, which was lacking something and was thin.   I took the advice of another reviewer and added some other ingredients to the sauce, namely peanut butter, brown sugar, a little ground ginger and a little bit of hot pepper flakes.  I also added a tablespoon of cornstarch in a slurry to thicken the sauce.  With those adjustments, the sauce was quite good.  However, as written, I would not have liked this recipe at all.  I don't understand all the rave reviews.

My husband can't cook. Like, AT ALL. But I forgot to start this before I left for work so I called him and told him how to do it over the phone. Took about 5ish minutes and was super easy... and it is totally one of our FAVORITE dishes. OMG it was so good! I left the recipe as is for the most part. I used bone-in chicken thighs and added some green onions when serving over a bed of jasmine rice. Otherwise, honey and soy sauce, etc were all kept the same. Next time we will add just a touch of crushed red pepper to give it a little zing, otherwise won't change anything. I didn't need to add anything to thicken the sauce since it was going over rice. 
Thanks so much for the recipe, it was amazing!!

text:
My family and I really loved this recipe.  I made it twice in three days, both times with 6 bl/sl thighs instead of 4.  The first time I followed the recipe exactly, and the general consensus was it was fabulous, but heavy on the soy sauce flavor.

So I switched the soy sauce and honey.  I did 1/2 cup of honey and 1/3 cup of soy sauce.  I also cooked it for an hour longer.  The chicken practically melted in my mouth and the honey-garlic flavors were much stronger, with the soy sauce as a yummy additive instead of monopolizing the whole meal.

country:

text:
I've made these dozens of times, and they are always a hit. The first few times, I followed the recipe exactly except used more chicken. I found this was enough sauce for 8-12 thighs. This is such a flexible recipe! Over time, I've baked this instead of using a slow cooker. I've changed the proportions of ingredients. Sometimes I use 1/2 cup each of soy sauce, ketchup, and honey. Sometimes, I halve the ketchup and make up the difference with an Asian sweet red chile sauce, and sometimes I substitute the sweet red chile sauce for the ketchup completely. We like to add tons of garlic and we almost always add ginger. The Ginger People ginger-sweet red chile sauce is awesome in this. We've never NOT liked whatever we've done with this recipe. I've used bone-in, skin-on thighs as well as boneless. They are all great! Thanks!!

Loved this.  The meat was fall off the bone.  And the flavor was outstanding.  I made exactly as written except I added another garlic clove since that's just our preference, and a 1/2 c. brown sugar to balance the soy sauce. Thanks!  p.s. for those of you who said too salty, use reduced sodium soy sauce or just use less.

text:
Haven't had much luck with new recipes lately...this ended that! This was so yummy :)I used 6 thighs and I used double the garlic and  I ,like other people , used cornstarch to thicken the juice up after....tried 1tbl but it only thickened a little  So  I used just a little more....I'm sure most people know how to add it but just in case this is how I did it....cold water mixed into the cornstarch in a small seperate container I removed the chicken ,put my slow cooker on high then stirred in the cornstarch mixture and stirred for a couple minutes.... Let it cook just a bit then returned the meat into the slow cooker and placed on warm and served... Was great with chicken stuffing drizzled the juice over the stuffing. Awesome!

text:
I used this recipe in my electric pressure cooker and it was marvelous!  I didn't change anything about the recipe except the cooking time.  In my 8 qt pressure cooker, I used the Soup/Stew setting for 10 minutes.  Like the slow-cooker instructions state, I just threw everything in the cooker together.  I manually released the steam and, as others suggested, thickened the sauce after taking out the chicken using a cornstarch slurry.  I asked the Hubs if I should rate it 4 or 5 stars and he immediately said "FIVE!"  Served with noodles and winter mix of vegetables, steamed with garlic.  Yum!

I changed the recipe to be a bit healthier.  I used Braggs Amino Liquid instead of soy sauce (which helped reduce the sodium and gave me a non-GMO soy flavor) and used free-range chicken breast instead of thighs.  The chicken was falling apart in 5 hrs and was thoroughly cooked at high altitude.  I steamed carrots in the rice steamer with the wild rice.  Fantastic dinner!!!

text:
This was very easy and straight forward to make. I used thighs with skin & bones (more flavor and the fat is easy to  get rid of later). I first put a decent crisp on the skin side of the thighs in a 12" non-stick skillet over med-high heat, also for more flavor. I put them in the slow cooker skin side down and then followed the recipe.  Next time I will try to shorten the cooking time because they were just a touch dry, probably because I jump started the cooking by starting them in a skillet? I used it for pulled chicken sandwiches and they were very tasty...

text:
Very good.  Put a layer of chopped onion in 1 T. butter in bottom of crock pot, then arranged frozen chicken breasts on top.  Cooked on high for a hour or so then added honey garlic mixture.  Continued on low for about two more hours then removed lid for last hour to cook off excess juices.  Note: The cooking time noted may be for the older crock pots that have lower cooking temperatures.

text:
I needed to tweak the basic sauce recipe. 1/4 cup soy sauce. 1/2 cup ketchup. 1/3 cup honey. 1/4 cup brown sugar. Large onion sliced. I tablespoon red crushed red pepper flakes. 3 cloves chopped garlic. Cooked on high one hour and then on low for 3 hours. I used 6 boneless skinless chicken thighs. Served with brown rice and roasted broccoli. It was absolutely delish!!! Don't forget to spoon extra sauce over rice and broccoli.  : )

text:
AWESOME dish. And SO easy! I did tweak the recipe per other reviewers suggestions: halved the soy and used low sodium, boiled down the "sauce" and thickened before serving, added a little ginger to the soy/honey/ketchup mix and only cooked for five hours. And I didn't have bone in skin on thighs... so boneless skinless it was! The meal was absolutely fantastic, infused with rich flavor. A very nice blend of salty and sweet without being too much of either. This will become a staple in my household as everyone loved it.

YA GOTTA TRY THIS!  Hubby ate seconds - he NEVER eats seconds, and the son moaned his way thru the meal.  Don't overcook; I did for maybe an hour and the chicken almost began to be tough.  Great flavor.  I opted for an easy meal after work and served this with rice-a-roni and cooked frozen english peas, thinking this would just get us through the evening.  My mistake - this was such a keeper!  Only change was using 1/3 cup of soy sauce instead of 1/2 cup. DO TRY THIS!  Thanks so much, Myrna!

This was delicious.  I had to make a few changes because I work long days and this recipe calls for it to cook for 6 hours.  I put my thighs in frozen.  Since I knew they would add water to the recipe I tweaked the ingredients a little bit.  I only used about 1/4 cup of soy sauce, (that was an accident, I ran out) I used 3/4c of ketchup and 3/4 cup of honey.  I also used 8 thighs and skipped the basil ( I did not have any) and cooked it on low for 9 hours.  It was fabulous.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I did this with a whole chicken, turned out great, simple and tasty - slow cooker chicken is tender but can be bland, this is a good way to give flavour. like another reviewer, I thickened the sauce  with cornflour, as the juices made it runny. I did this on the stove top but  I think you can do it in the slow cooker if you add the cornflour slurry say half an hour before serving. A whole chicken might need more time or a higher setting (usual advice is 4-5 hours on High), and more fat will run off so you'll probably need to skim the sauce if you want to try this.

text:
I followed the recipe exactly, the only thing I did first was brown my chicken thighs in a little hot oil to get a nice crispy golden crust on it. Then I tossed it all in the crock pot added the sauce. Chicken was tender, juicy and good but a little on the greasy side. The flavor just wasn't Asian enough for me. I think a little ginger & hot sauce would have given it more of that Asian flare. Not bad, but needs tweaking for my personal taste.

text:
I loved this recipe as did all the guests at the pot luck dinner I took them.  I did not have 6 hours to cook them so I put them in a 9x13 pan and baked them at 325 degrees for and hour or so until done.  I then put thighs in the crock pot to take to the pot luck and everyone loved them. So if you do not have the time bake first then transfer to the crock pot to keep them warm and everyone will rave about them.  Thanks for this recipe as it will be used often.

text:
I'll be honest, I almost didn't make this bc of the soy sauce/ketchup combo. I read the comments, a lot of positive ones. A few people said they subbed BBQ sauce for ketchup.  I had 1 pack of thighs, which was 3 lbs, maybe 10 thighs. I used 1/2 cup soy sauce, 1/4 cup each of BBQ sauce & ketchup. I only had garlic powder,  few dashes of sesame oil & a small can of crushed pineapple (I assume it was an 8 oz can) Cooked on high for 3 hours. Came out perfectly! I will have to buy 2 packs of chicken next time & double recipe. I'm glad I made it. Even picky teen had 2 helpings. We ate with side of rice & broccoli florets.

text:
First of all, there is no way that you can cook this for 6 hours!!! I temped it after 2 1/2 hours and it was done. At first  I thought this was going to have an Asian flavor, but it turned out more like a bbq sauce. I did half the basil, thinking this was kind of a strange spice to add. Halfing it created a very slight basil flavor with an unique taste. I ended up slicing the chicken across the grain and serving it as sandwiches on toasted garlic toast, and topped in with a bit of tangy coleslaw. It was a great recipe served this way. Which is the only way I will serve it in the future.

text:
Put this in the crockpot before I left for work at noon so the hubs wouldn‚Äôt have to stress for dinner. Made the sauce in a pan and heated it up, added cornstarch slurry. Poured it over the six chicken thighs (they we partially frozen) added some cut up frozen bell peppers, a dash of ginger and some dehydrated chopped onion. Cut the soy sauce in half. Set that baby on low, cooked for six hours. The family LOVED IT! Hubs only had to make rice and roast broccoli. Easy peasy!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4482864.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has been in my saved recipes for a while...Minimal, staple pantry items thrown in a crockpot, what‚Äôs not to love? I had a tray of 12 small, boneless, skinless chicken thighs but numerous people commented that increasing the amounts was not necessary and that turned out to be true. I had misgivings about using ketchup so ended up using BBQ sauce instead. As always when using soy sauce in recipes, I use the low sodium version.  I also added about a tablespoon of crushed red pepper to spice it up. As others suggested, after 5 hours in the crockpot, I put the sauce in a saucepan and added cornstarch to thicken it up which I drizzled over the chicken and some brown rice. I would make again but it‚Äôs not one of my favorites.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
I just made this tonight after seeing the video a few days ago & knowing I had all the ingredients in my pantry, and I LOVE chicken thighs vs breast.
I placed my frozen 4 thighs & 2 breasts in my crockpot, made the sauce, and poured over chicken.  Set it for 6 hrs on low as the recipe states.  When it was finished, my crockpot had about a 1/2 inch of liquid sauce in the bottom and my chicken looked nothing like the picture.  It was not a thick glaze but more of a liquid soup.  Sooo disappointing.  The only thing the sauce did was perhaps infiltrate the meat, but EVERY SINGLE PIECE OF MEAT was totally dry, even the thighs.  The breasts were even worse.
I don't know how this recipe failed as I followed every step correctly, but this will not be a keeper for our family.  Very disappointed.

text:
Made in my Instant Pot. Added pineapple tidbits and some juice and used frozen chicken thighs. 15 minutes, then 15 minutes natural release. I then removed the chicken to an oven proof dish, and thickened the sauce with cornstarch on Saute. Placed the sauce in the dish over the chicken and baked at 450 for about 10 minutes.

I doubled the sauce recipe with 12 chicken thighs. It was an easy work night meal. It missing a little depth though.  Maybe next time I'll add in some sliced onions and peppers. One thing I will say is 4 to 4 1/2 hours on low in the crockpot is enough for us. When chicken is in the crockpot so long it becomes so tender it's almost mushy.  we like our chicken to still feel like meat. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Delicious! I used 8 pieces of boneless/skinless chicken thighs and legs (2 sections from the Costco package). I used low sodium soy sauce and reduced that to 1/3 cup. I used BBQ instead of ketchup (I think someone mentioned it in a review, not sure though). Anyway, it was delicious! I may cut back a little on the honey if I use BBQ again next time. It didn't taste too sweet at all, but that adds up to a good amount of sugar. I had a cup or more of the sauce left over and froze that. Not sure what I'll do with it... maybe use it as a marinade for grilled chicken? I also used the leftover chicken on top of my salad the next day. 
Overall very delicious and VERY cheap recipe. Thanks for posting it!!

text:
Just a little mention - I would use slow cooker liners to save on mess/cleanup instead of aluminum foil as mentioned, as it has been strongly suggested that tomato products (in this case, ketchup) leaches the aluminum out of the foil, and contributes to Alzheimers.  I've seen the black residue that has come off on the food when I've covered lasagna!  Otherwise the recipe is AWESOME!

text:
I logged on at 1pm and was eating dinner by 6:30. I followed the recipe exactly, for ingredients. Cooked on high for 2 hours, and low for 3 hours. I removed the thighs , added a slurry of cornstarch and water to thicken juices, turned back to high for a few minutes and dinner was ready. Served with a brown rice/quinoa mix with dried cherries, and broccoli. It was a quick delicious meal that had tender, moist chicken. Definitely a keeper.

text:
I have made this recipe 3 times so far and EVERY ONE of my 3 picky teenagers loves it. The only thing I did differently was add 1/4 cup ketchup instead 1/2 cup, and 1/2 cup Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ sauce.  The trick for our family? Pull the chicken out and shred it in a bowl, serve with the sauce on the side. Didn't love it as much when I put the sauce over the top before serving.  We eat this with a microwaved bag of sticky rice and a salad on the side.  Sooo yummy!  Is now part of our regular menu.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We've made the version of this recipe that was featured in one of their magazines and it was for 8 chicken breasts. The ingredient amounts were a little different - 2/3 cup soy sauce, 2/3 cup ketchup, 1/3 cup honey, 4 cloves garlic, 1 tsp basil, 1/2 tsp salt, 1/2 tsp pepper; put the chicken in a plastic bag, pour the sauce mix in, massage the bag and let sit for at least an hour in the fridge, then grill them. Best grilled chicken I've ever had. I recommend using all the sauce in the bag, just get a rubber brush and brush it on while it's on the grill.

Considering the title includes honey and garlic I expected those to be the dominant flavors. Especially since i used twice as much garlic as called for. Or, after reading the reviews maybe a poor excuse for teriyaki. Instead, the predominant flavor was ketchup. I guess if you have kids it might make a good family meal but overall I'm counting this as a recipe fail.

text:
This is actually a great and very simple recipe. I've changed a few things up over time, but the basic premise is spot on. Like many, I upped the number of thighs as the BS thighs shrink to nothing, so for a family of 4 (3 men) I use 12. In the past I've subbed chili sauce (the one in that cute glass jar) for the ketchup, and I have some habanero honey I'll use when I make it again tonight. I make a coconut jasmine rice (recipe somewhere here on AR), and I tell you, my men eat like they've never seen food. Makes me happy. I think I'll toss in a bunch of green beans and snap peas toward the end this time, too. 4 hours on high, 6-8 hours on low. Voila!

text:
I was not swept off my feet by this recipe.  Around the 3rd hour I noticed a "done" smell in the kitchen, so I checked the temp of the meat and it was done, in the verge of being overcooked. I can't believe the recipe called for 6 hours on low. No way! Or perhaps my slow coroner's low temperature is higher than normal. At any rate, I think this might have turned out better had the chicken soaked in the mixture for 30 minutes or longer to absorb the flavors.

text:
Its very tasty but reduce the cooking time. Going the full six hours seriously dries out the meat, even while submerged. I did this again yesterday with 10 boneless/skinless for 5 hours and were at 190 degrees after hour 4 on low. Had to turn it down to warm to time the rest of the meal. Tip:  use reduced sodium soy sauce. SO much tastier.

text:
I have made this recipe many times over the last several years. It is one of my husbands favorites. The only change I make is I cut the soy sauce back to 1/4 cup when using regular soy sauce and I add a few whole garlic cloves into the crock pot as well.  Sometimes I'll throw in a couple quartered vidallia onions. I've made it with thighs, quarters, even whole chicken. It's also good with rabbit as well, but watch for bones. If using bone in chicken the meat falls off the bones. Delicious recipe!

text:
Easy, minimal ingredients, budget friendly, flavorful.  What's not to like.  Based on another review, I tossed in a bit of chopped onion I had in the freezer and some red pepper flakes because I like spicy things.  Used 8 boneless/skinless thighs since someone mentioned freezing (and I love things I can freeze to make a busy weeknight easy).  Had lots of sauce, served over white rice - what I had on hand.  The only "complaint" I might have is my thighs fell apart. And they were huge!  I would prefer they remain intact if serving to company, but hey!  That's not much of a complaint, is it?

text:
In my opinion, if I make this again, I will add a little more garlic and thicken up the sauce a bit so that it coats the chicken, rather than the thighs just sitting in the sauce.  Also, I think marinating the thighs overnight will add a little more flavor to them.

I will say this, it does not need to cook for 6 hours on low. Four hours will do the trick. It over cooked and dried out my chicken. The sauce had a little bit of a burnt taste to it.  Trial and error. Next time I know what to tweak.

text:
If you double the ‚Äúsauce‚Äù you can make about 3 pounds of (boneless/skinless) chicken. I like to combine thighs and breasts. Add some ginger and a tablespoon of brown sugar. I (break up and) throw in the chicken FROZEN. Cook on LOW for four hours. Then, remove the chicken (I like to break it into smaller pieces) and crank up your crock pot to HIGH. Sprinkle and whisk in some flour (just a little at a time so it‚Äôs not lumpy). Add the chicken back in... yum! Great recipe!

userID:
1956088
Display Name:
Bonnie Hartnett
isPro:

followersCount:
0

2

84
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1367367.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a good base recipe but needed some add ins for better flavor and texture. I used 8 boneless skinless thighs and started with half the amount of soy sauce listed and then added a bit more at the end. The amount needed could vary quite a bit depending on what brand you have on hand. Lachoy or kikoman are gonna taste like salt bombs compared to some other brands. I added garlic powder, a drizzle of sesame oil,  1/4 tsp of Chinese 5 spice, some diced onion,  about 1/4 cup brown sugar  and a couple heaping Tbsps of chilli garlic sauce. Mixed well so chicken was coated then sprinkled a Tbs of  cornstarch over everything and mixed well again. If you bought your crockpot after the 90s it will cook much hotter on low so either cut your cook time back to 3 1/2 HOURS  (checking at 3) or set it at warm to cook. Mine comes to a simmer at warm.
Review:

text:
The recipe looked delicious. As I was preparing it, I was so excited to taste the scrumptious looking chicken.

When it was cooking, I could only smell the overpowering soy sauce mixed with the Ketchup.

When it finally came out of the pot, I was disgusted. What met my eyes was black looking logs that looked like brownies. It tasted even worse. 

My mother who has cooked Taiwanese meals for generations, told me that soy sauce is generally used with tablespoons and not cups, as that is way too much sodium. 

I will give this recipe again, but instead of the enormous amount of sodium, I will try less of everything (except the chicken of course)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I, too, feared this would be too salty from the amount of soy sauce, but was proven wrong!
I was definitely drawn in by the apparent ease of the recipe, and the flavors blended wonderfully. I went with from-frozen, boneless, skinless thighs (wish I had put in MORE!) and left the recipe basically unchanged. I added only a little dried chopped onions instead of the green (just to hide from my very picky household,)  and used pre-minced garlic rather than chopping whole cloves.

I shortened the time by cooking on high for 2 hours, then low for a little less than one additional. That gave me time to prepare the accompanying  Balsamic Roasted Red Potatoes (from this site.)
I also thickened the remaining liquid with a cornstarch slurry, and have much sauce/glaze remaining. With the wonderful flavor profile, I WILL be using it again soon. It would be great over plain white rice, as flavor, but I had prepared cheesy rice for this meal.

Thank you for sharing, thumbs up from us!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made with 10 boneless thighs and added 1 teaspoon dried oregano, some pepper flakes, extra garlic and some dry onion flakes.  Also removed the thighs at the end of cooking and thickened the sauce with some corn starch and put the thighs back for 15 min, turning the crock-pot on high. I used low sodium Soy Sauce as well. 
Cooked on high for 20 min, then turned to low for 4 1/2 hours before removing thighs and thickening sauce. Meat was very tender, falling apart. 

I actually thought it was a little under-seasoned, so next time will rub the thighs with kosher salt and pepper before cooking, and some extra pepper flakes and increase the dry onion and maybe add some ground ginger,  but overall it was tasty. Paired the meat with white rice and roasted garlic green and white beans, and baby carrots.

text:
well, since hubby expressed how much he liked it twice while eating, I'll give this 5 stars.  Also 5 stars for ease.  I added the ketchup, honey, (2x) garlic and soy in glass measuring cup and poured over the thighs in the crock pot.  Viola.  Done and done. The last hour of cooking I put in some sliced onions.  When we were about 15 mins from eating I took the chicken out and turned the crock pot on high and added a slurry of pineapple juice and cornstarch.  The sauce thickened up quite nicely.  Served with green beans and quinoa.  Will make again.   Thanks for the post!

text:
This was super easy and super tasty!
I browned the chicken first in a little butter and olive oil before transferring it to the slow cooker.
I also added thin sliced yellow onions, about teaspoon of red chilli flakes,  maybe a teaspoon of white pepper and the juice from half a lemon to the soy/ketchup marinade. I poured most of the marinade over the chicken and then used the remaining marinade and about 1/4 cup of water to deglaze the pan I browned the chicken in. Then poured the pan drippings into the stock pot.
It was so delicious served over rice. Next time, I will serve it over garlic fried rice!

text:
This was an easy recipe to use as a starting point. I added an onion small bag of peeled carrots and a can of water chestnuts to the chicken before pouring the sauce over it. I also doubled the recipe but used only 1/2  a cup of honey instead of 2/3, as would have been required if I had doubled the honey as well. I thickened the sauce with cornstarch by making a slurry with 3 TBSPs cornstarch and 6 TBSP water and mixing that in for the last 15 minutes of cooking. I put the crock pot back up to high for those 15 minutes.

text:
I generally follow a recipe precisely the first time I make it and did so this time, even though I thought it had way too much soy sauce in it.  I was right - it was way too much soy sauce!  In addition, the sauce did not cook down into a "glaze" on the chicken but instead produced a lot of liquid.  I removed the chicken when it was about done, put it in the oven with a little of the sauce to keep it from drying out and then reduced the sauce on the stove top for at least half an hour.  It was still not thick enough to be called a glaze.  My husband requested that I not make this again and wasn't particularly interested in eating the left-overs.  I doubt I'd even try altering the recipe to make this one a second time.

the guy in the kitchen

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! I kept the sauce ingredients as describeb but I used 6 bone-in thighs with the skin and cooked it in a 7 quart oval crock pot on low for 6 hours. These were cooked perfectly. The meat just fell off the bones.
I strained the sauce and sprinkled  the strained out minced garlic  over the chicken. I then used some of the separated grease from the strained sauce and some flour to make a rue. Then used the rue to thicken the sauce to gravy constincy.  I served it with steamed rice and fresh steamed broccoli.
This was delicous the first day but it did not re-heat vey well the next day.
Review:

1

text:
This was yummy and I was able to make it with pantry items I always have. I used 3 packages (of the 6 package bag) of CostCo chicken thighs which would be about 10 thighs. I decided to double the sauce and I could have gotten away with not doing so. My crockpot tends to run hot and I set the timer for 6 hours on low but at 5 hours it was a little on the overdone side and next time I'll cook it for 4 1/2 instead. I served it with mashed potatoes and it was a hit!

text:
I loved this. After decades of cooking you run out of things you aren't sick of. This is so easy and flavourful I'm happy to add it to the rotation. We didn't find it too salty but I did add a small amount more of honey and spiced it up a bit with a sprinkling of red chili flakes. Super easy.
UPDATE: I think that being too salty depends on what type of soya sauce you use. They are not all the same. A good Chinese soya sauce tends to be less salty and thicker. The Japanese version is quite a bit saltier and watery.  That has been my experience.

I followed the recipe but had about 4 lbs. of boneless, skinless chicken thighs and it worked out fine.  I was hoping it would be a little sweeter though.  Still it was good enough for the husband and kids to enjoy.  The sauce seemed to thicken by itself, so I didn't add any corn starch or anything.  I think I might just experiment with a little more sugar next time to make it a little sweeter though.  I served it with simple jasmine rice and garlic green beans.  Oh, and I did speed up the cooking by turning it on high in the last hour.  It was like 3 hours of slow cook time and 1 hour on high.

None
country:
None
text:
I like to try a recipe exactly as written the first time, so that is what I did.  I had more chicken thighs on hand than the recipe calls for (I had 8 smallish ones), but otherwise followed the sauce recipe exactly.  The chicken was well cooked in 5 hours on low.  The sauce was very watery/greasy, and so I removed some of the oil with the lettuce leaf method.  Then I cooked the sauce in a saucepan with a cornstarch slurry, and added red pepper flakes to give it a bit more punch.  It wasn't "fine-dining", but it was tasty.  I will make this again for my son, who loves dark meat chicken, because it is super-easy, and I like the fact that  you can just fix it and forget it.

This was a great start for the recipe, but I had to make a lot of changes.  First I reduced the soy sauce to 1 tablespoon and the ketchup to 1/4 cup.  I used 1 big spoon full of pre-minced garlic ( from a jar).  I added 1 teaspoon of garlic powder and salt and pepper to taste. I omitted the dried basil because I din't have any . And I used 1/2 cup of honey ( I used Nature Nate's Raw &  Unfiltered Honey from Costco)  All said and done it came out great and my husband LOVED IT!  I will definitely make this again.

region:

country:
None
text:
This ended up tasting like a good sweet and sour sauce chicken. I cooked cubed chicken breasts on the stove and used the sauce for a stir fry because I didn't have time to use the slow cooker. From other's suggestions, I reversed the amounts for the soy sauce and the honey, using a low-sodium soy sauce. Upped the garlic to 5 cloves. Added powdered ginger and red pepper flakes to sauce. When I tasted the sauce before cooking it, it didn't taste that great, but the taste improved once cooked down. Added frozen veggies, onions,  and a can of sliced pineapples at the end. I would make this again!

text:
I did not care for this recipe. I followed the directions, except I used 9 small thighs, and the sauce was completely soupy. I decided to take others' advice and strained the sauce into a pan and added cornstarch to thicken. I then spooned a little sauce back onto the thighs and put in the oven on 450 for about 20 minutes. It made the  sauce stick to the thighs, but I still did not like the flavor. I used low sodium soy sauce, so it was not too salty, but all I could taste was the soy sauce and the ketchup. I couldn't taste the honey or garlic. I won't be making this one again. Sorry.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3484958.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this and used Autumn's suggested extra ingredients - ginger, onion and red pepper flakes. I also used low sodium soy sauce.  I used smaller thighs and was able to put 9 thighs in a 4 quart crock pot and there was plenty of sauce.  I cooked on high for two hours and low for about another two hours -  The chicken was was right temp at 2 hours but I felt like the onion (small chopped) needed a little extra time.  The sauce was thick enough for us, but if you want more of a glaze then straining and using cornstarch is a good idea.
Wonderful flavors, easy to make and quick to cook.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious chicken recipe. I cooked it low and slow in the crock pot (8 hours). The longer the chicken cooks the more intense the flavors so I HIGHLY recommend using reduced sodium soy sauce, I'm glad I did. The chicken came out looking just like the picture. Some reviewers said they had to thicken the sauce with corn starch, I think that was probably because they cooked it for a shorter amount of time. My sauce came out nice and thick, not too thick though. I served with brown rice and broccoli and topped the chicken with additional sauce and toasted sesame seeds. Yummy. Leftovers tonight yea!This is a definite keeper.

text:
Let me start with saying, I am not a fan of dark meat AT ALL!  My husband is so I thought I would give this recipe a shot!!  This recipe is so yummy !!! I mixed all of the liquids together, heavy on the garlic added garlic powder and carmelized onions.  Put a little bit of the sauce in the bottom of the crock pot put 6 skinned bone in thighs, the thick side down and poured the rest of the sauce on the thighs!  Cooked in low for 4 hours!  The sauce on the chicken was glazed and the meat fell off the bone!  This is the only way I will eat chicken thighs! EVERYONE loved it even my picky husband!  I will make this over and over again....and it's so EASY!  Thank you for sharing !

I absolutely love this flavor! I would like to say that I made this recipe as written, but I guess technically I didn't. Since I used chicken breast ribbed meat and marinated it for about a whole day; give or take an hour or 2. Also, I didn't poke holes in the chicken. With that being said, I do prefer thighs and drumsticks; and believe that this would have been even better if I had used thighs.  I did not thicken or even use the sauce and it was still delicious! Thanks for sharing!

text:
It was a good base, but the sauce came out extremely watery no matter what I did. I added some jarred, minced ginger, decreased the soy slightly because I read reviews that said it was too salty. I also omitted the honey and used about a 1/4 cup brown sugar. It was very good and my chicken actually fell apart in the slow cooker. I stir fried some veggies and cooked some rice. There was more than enough sauce to coat it all.

I followed this recipe pretty much as written except doubled the chicken because 4 thighs are not enough to feed a family of 4.  I did not double the sauce because there was still enough to cover 8 pieces of chicken.  I always use salt-reduced soya sauce.  I had fresh basil available.  The chicken was alright on the outside but dry on the inside. The sauce was just okay.  I have tried many fantastic chicken thigh recipes over the years and this was not one of the better ones!  We all ate it but no one in the family loved it enough to warrant making it again.

text:
Made it per the recipe. 

For my palette, I found:
1. The chicken was a bit too salty (use less soy and use low sodium soy)
2. The overall flavor was a bit too sweet (reduce the honey - 1/3 cup is too much)
3. The meat was tender slow cooker, but the dish was done in 4-5 hours, not 6
4. I had to reduce the sauce - too wet to be served either on the chicken or rice straight from the SC.

I won't make it again, since it was just "OK" for me; on to other and new recipes.

text:
Since there was so much sauce, I used 14 boneless, skinless chicken thighs. I read other reviews and cooked it in the slow cooker on low for 5 hours, instead of 6 hours. It came out perfect (with still plenty of sauce leftover). I didn't put any corn starch to thicken it and although it was a little watery, I didn't mind. The thighs were served it over white basmati rice. My husband rated it a 'A'! I will definitely make this again! The only thing I would change next time is using a low sodium soy sauce.

userID:
21242061
Display Name:
KAK
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
159
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5679855.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Spray the slow cooker with cooking spray.  Clean up was easy. 
I used 8 smallish, boneless, skinless chicken thighs. Mixed up the sauce using 1 1/2 tsp garlic powder,  1 1/2 tsp. dried basil, 
2 T brown sugar. Same amount of soy sauce (low sodium), ketchup and honey that is in the recipe.  Poured this over the thighs and topped the whole thing with about 1/2 bag of frozen mixed pepper strips. 
This was done perfectly in 3 1/2 hours on low. Thickened the sauce in another pot by mixing up 1T cornstarch with 1/8 cup cold water. Whisk it into the sauce and heat to a simmer.  Pour over the thighs. 
Served it over rice.  Easy, peasy and very good.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

As is, the sauce was pretty sweet and very "tomatoey".  With some additions it turned into a great dish. I marinated the chicken in the sauce for a few hours and saut√©ed in a pan until the chicken was almost shreddable.   Will make again with the additions.

text:
Excellent flavor! Entire family loved it. I only gave it four stars because I believe the recipe is a bit faulty. First of all,  I used 6 thighs....but found with the amount of sauce that I could have cooked 8 or 10 and had plenty of sauce. Also, after reading other reviews I watched the time carefully. at 3 hours 45 minutes the chicken was done. If I had cooked the entire 6 hours it would have been ruined. 
I added a bit more fresh, ground ginger and some sesame oil and 2 tablespoons very very teriyaki bc I was short a bit on soy sauce. Wonderful flavor.

I made this dish according to the recipe, as far as ingredients.  I didn't have time to cook it in the crockpot, so I browned the chicken with the garlic in olive oil,  then put it in a glass casserole dish, poured the sauce over it and baked it in the oven at 400 degrees for about 20 minutes.  It came out moist and very tasty, and was great for a quick dinner.  I served it with yellow rice and salad. The only thing I changed, as far as ingredients was to use low-sodium soy sauce.  I'll definitely make it again!

text:
My family LOVED this and the recipe is now in our Family FavorItes collection. I put half the sauce on for the first half of cooking and added the remainder for the last half.  I also drained off the excess "watery" fluid that accumulated at the beginning. We served ours with Jasmine rice and steamed broccoli. Next time I think we'll serve it with egg noodles. The ingredients are staples in our pantry so this recipe works real well for our family. An easy to put together meal. My family & I highly recommend this recipe.

text:
Easy and delicious! I used 6 bone-in chicken thighs instead of four. In the interest of saving a few minutes in the morning I wisked all the sauce ingredients together the night before so I just had to lay the chicken in the slow cooker and pour the sauce over them just before leaving for work. The only minor change I made was the addition of about 2T ghost blueberry hot sauce. Since some people wrote that 6 hours was too much I set the crock on low for 5 hours. The chicken was perfect. I understand why some people think its too salty but both hubs and I were fine with the amount of saltiness in the finished dish. One of the other reviewers mentioned coconut rice so I went with that. It was a good compliment. I'll make this again. Thanks!

None
text:
Loved it! Its easy and quick to make as well as delicious! My partner loved it as well making this a win-win!  I did follow other reviews using 6 boneless skinless chicken thighs. I also added corn starch as others suggested to thicken the sauce at the end. To do this I removed the chicken thighs, whisked the corn starch with cold water to blend (otherwise corn starch will clump when mixed into anything warm) and poured into sauce mixing well until I got my desired consistency. Served chicken with sauce over brown rice. Definitely will be making this recipe again!!

I just don't understand posters that say it was too salty or it was overcooked. Use low sodium soy sauce for one thing and also check the chicken after a couple hours to see if it's cooked. Mine was done in 3 hours. It's not rocket science.
That being said I had to leave when I put it in the crockpot and when I came home about 3 hours later it was done so I didn't have time to do anything else to it. Made it exactly as it was written. Husband said the sauce was "Ok, not bad" and I thought it was pretty good but I think I'll leave out the basil next time. To me it just gave a weird taste. I also didn't have any garlic so I had to use granulated garlic so I'm sure that had something to do with the final result. I will try again though using plenty of garlic and maybe add some green peppers to it.

Making it again today, increasing the amount of chicken again, so we can repurpose it all week.  Ideas right now include over roasted eggplant, quesadillas, and some type of stuffed pepper.

I followed the recipe exactly.  I planned my dinner to be served after 5 hours in case it got done early. 
Well, I bet it was done in 3 hours! We were out of the house when cooking.  
They shrunk down to little medallions and were dry and overcooked.  I used my 4 qt. Slow cooker on low setting. I cooked 6 pieces. 
It smelled so good.  I was really looking forward to it. 
I will not make the chicken this way again. But, I will try it on stovetop or in the oven. And, a much, much, shorter time. 
And it was too salty.  I thought it might be, so I used low sodium soy sauce.  Still too much.

This is a keeper and I know I will make this again.

userID:
21523332
Display Name:
Pauline Pappas Fox
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3

0
madeRecipesCount:
0
favoritesCount:
13
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe as written first.  It made too much sauce for the amount of chicken. The chicken was dry-too long cooking time. The worst part it was just too salty for me, even using   Low sodium soy sauce. 

I made several adjustments that made it a pretty good dish.  Here are the changes:
1. Cut soy sauce by half. 
2. Add 1 extra clove garlic
3. Add 1/4 c. brown sugar to sauce
4. Cut one dozen baby carrots in half-add on top of chicken
5. Add 1/4 yellow onion cut into rings to bottom of pan. 
6. Add 1/2 of a large red pepper diced on top of chicken. 
7. 2 hours into cooking pour a 20 oz can of pineapple chunks (juice and fruit) over top.  Stir in. 
8. Cook a total of 4 hours - the first two hours on high, the 2nd two in low. 
9.  Serve over steamed rice.  

I have served it with both thickened sauce and thin. Tasty either way.
I understand my version is not the same recipe -but if I were to base the rating  on the original, it would only receive 1 star.
Review:
Rating:
5

userID:
6998633
Display Name:
Chavez Family
isPro:

0

0
madeRecipesCount:
6
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I thought this quite good - here's what I did with 8 boneless skinless chicken thighs which I trimmed for fat. I have a large crockpot - so the # of chicken thighs should be equal to what covers the bottom of your crock pot without too much bunching up and no overlap. It turned out great, and I cooked at 2.5 hours high. In the last 1 hour I added a diced bell pepper, 1 8 oz package of sliced mushrooms, and 1 medium onion chopped. I finished by broiling the thighs themselves on high for 5 minutes, and put a slurry (roughly 1/8 cup cornstarch with cold water, whisked until smooth) of cornstarch in to thicken the sauce.

-8 skinless boneless chicken thighs
-1/2 cup low sodium soy sauce
-1/3 cup ketchup 
-1/3 cup honey 
-6 cloves garlic, minced
-1 full teaspoon ginger paste (or fresh ginger, grated)
-1 half teaspoon ground white pepper
-1 full spoon chili garlic paste

I have been struggling to find good slow cooker recipes, I hate how food turns out soupy and mushy but this is perfect!

text:
Loved it.  I used 1/3 c. Soya sauce, 1/4 c ketchup, 1/4 c  Sweet Baby Ray's sweet and spicey BBQ sauce, 1/3 c honey, .garlic, 1/2 tsp ginger and chopped up a small onion. Added cornstarch to thicken at end.  With 5 chicken thighs which were a good size, it took 5 hours on low to cook.  It makes lots of sauce.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
When I made this I doubled the recipe and used my larger crock pot.  I reduced the cooking time about an hour and a half, as this newer crock pot seems to cook hotter, and the chicken was cooked perfectly.  I substituted half Braggs Aminos for the soy sauce  and removed the chicken after cooking and thickened the sauce with cornstarch, I then replaced the chicken, broke it up and served it over rice.  I personally found it a bit salty, although still tasty; my family loved it and second portions were had by several.  It was a quick (minus cooking time)  and easy meal to feed a larger group.  I will make it again, probably completely substituting Braggs Aminos for the soy sauce.

Well, this is the first time I've ever rated a recipe negatively. I think I can now say that any recipe that calls for catsup should be suspect. I believe this recipe reminds me of consuming fresh zombies basted in a broth of their own squish. You contemplate digging your tongue out of your mouth with the sharpest knife you can find. You wonder to yourself - is it just me? I guess it could be so... After a great deal of thought I would have to say -  do yourself a favor, walk away from this recipe as fast as you can. cheers!

Made this for the 1st time ... followed the recipe, but felt there was a lot of sauce.  After cooking for 3 hrs., because of the smell, I felt I better check the meat .. glad I did. text:
This was a very solid recipe! I made it with eight chicken thighs. I expanded the recipe a little bit since it only called for four chicken thighs. I added some baby carrots since I had them on hand.  I removed the chicken thighs and put them in a glass dish and broiled them for five minutes to crisp up the thighs and it made a huge difference, I believe.  It did look exactly like the picture on the recipe. Some  of the reviews said it was too salty, but it would only be too salty if you kept adding the sauce to  other side dishes. I had quite a bit of sauce left over, but I did not use it.  This recipe could be used for any number of meats. It's a keeper!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2017-01-09T23:30:32.937
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
7155517

Lynn
isPro:

text:
This was pretty good the first go around, but I would make some alterations for next time.   First the sauce is too salty and there's WAY WAY WAY too much sauce at the end.   Either add 3X on the chicken or cut the sauce in half using maybe low sodium soy.   I probably doubled the amount of thighs (since 4 thighs is not that much) and still I had a pool of leftover sauce.   It's not a show stopper, but it's easy, which is probably why it made the "best of 2016" recipe list.

country:
None
text:
My wife requests these chicken thighs quite often.  I usually adjust the quantities upward, as these make a good meal to share with others.  They are always moist and flavorful, and they melt in your mouth.  The flavor from the sauce is wonderful, and these are especially good as leftovers, if there are any!  The batch I am in the process of making consists of (6) chicken thighs, which is the smallest batch I have made.  I usually make between (12) and (18) thighs at a time, but I have not had to increase the amount of sauce, which is why they never come out looking like the photo.  If you want to make a chicken dish that people will request on a regular basis, this is it!  I think I will thicken up the sauce, as some have requested, and spoon it over rice.  This recipe is a keeper!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The flavors were great and I have a slow cooker that has a probe that you set for an internal temp of the chicken and then it switches to "warm" mode so as not to over cook chicken. I used breasts instead of thighs. My disappointment was that this recipe didn't make a glaze. It made a soup. It was purely liquid. I was hoping to not have any additional work on the meal with it being a crock pot meal. But I had to take the "soup" out of the crock pot and heat it with cornstarch on the stove to thicken it to a glaze, brush it onto the chicken, and cook in the oven to set it. I did put carrots and sliced baby reds in the crock pot with the chicken as well, and added some green beans the last 30 minutes. Served over quinoa.

userID:
17651679
Display Name:
Danielle Smith
isPro:
False
followersCount:
7
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
9
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Few modifications I made: used bone in/skin on thighs. Meat was falling off the bone - didn't even need a knife. Cooked on high for 2:30 instead. Chopped a small white onion and dropped in with chicken from the start. Added a shake of red pepper flakes to the seasoning/sauce. When it was done,  I put the thighs skin down in a medium hot frying pan to sear the skin and make it crispy (took less than a minute). Added cornstarch to sauce at the end. Served with jasmine rice and the garlic broccoli recipe on here (roasted in oven).  Whole family scarfed it down including my 1.5 year old! Enjoy :)

text:
As others mentioned, it does come out a bit soupy but can be thickened up easily. While the overall flavor is reminiscent of teriyaki, the soy is too prominent and the garlic non-existent. I will try this recipe once more but will half the soy, add two more cloves of garlic, some red pepper flakes, and maybe a tablespoon of brown sugar so the sweetness comes out a bit more. 
Chicken in a slow cooker is always fall apart. Ain't nothing wrong with that.

I only had 2 chicken thighs but halved the other ingredients, though I used low sodium soy sauce.  Didn't cook as long due to less volume.  I removed the chicken to shred for tacos. Thank you Myrna for sharing this amazing recipe!

Display Name:
Linda

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I threw this together and shoved it in the oven instead of making it in the crock pot the next day as I had planned to do - and it was great!  Big hit -  I used bone in thighs as that's what I had on hand, used the same amount of garlic but otherwise  halved the sauce, used less salt (I always use less salt in recipes)  cooked it covered at about 375 for an hour in the oven, then uncovered it for a little while.  They were overcooked, so next time I'll shorten the time.   I also put some baking potatoes and a cut up wrapped in foil butternut squash in the same oven,  so viola, a simple tasty dinner with almost no hands on time.  There was enough sauce for 6 thighs in my opinion.  Not sure if I'll ever get around to trying it in the crock pot, but I'll definitely be making this again.   Next time I'll grate some fresh ginger in the sauce, it seems to need a little something zesty, although it's good as is. Looks pretty too, which is always a plus.

text:
I am a teacher in Beijing, China. And this recipe reminds me of a lot of dishes that I can find in small restaurants. I changed two things. First, I found a package of drumettes in the market that I go to so I used them instead of chicken thighs. I kept the recipe as stated and the only other change I made was to pop the drumettes under the broiler for about 10 minutes. This was supposed to be my quick lunches for the week, but it was all I could do not to eat them in one sitting! Very savory and delicious!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this following the instructions listed. I made only a few changes which include half of a sweet onion, a 1/2 tsp of ground ginger (but could up it to 3/4 tsp next time), 1/2 tsp of red pepper flakes (but could increase it to 3/4 tsp next time). It only took a little over 3 hrs in the crockpot on high, I took it out an broiled it for a few minutes after spooning some of the sauce in it. I thickened the sauce remaining in the crock pot with corn starch & used my stick blender to cut break up the onions. I served with baby peas & brown rice & a nice red blend of wine. Very good, both my BF and family enjoyed it. Will be making this again.

Made this for my family while I was at work.   So simple/ easy to make!   Smelt wonderfully.   Came home ready to eat some and it was all gone.   Family loved it!   I will make again soon for them and myself. I did use boneless skinless thighs and lite soy sauce.  Thank you so much.
2-15-17. I have made this wonderful recipe several times now.  Always a perfect hit.   I do double the recipe every time.  I also take some of the sauce and poor it in to a sauce pan.  I add some floor to make a roux.  I pour roux back in to crock and mix it up.  This makes a great sauce to have on top of rice or mashed potatoes.  This is one of my families favorite recipes on this sight!  Love it.

userID:

Display Name:
DENNI HAUSBACK
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3963353.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Less ketchup, light soy to reduce the saltiness(medical reasons not taste) boiled in chicken broth or Better than Boullion. Small amount of unsalted butter keeps it from sticking if your work day is longer than the 6hr cooking time. Splash of rice wine vinegar. Dash of Red pepper Flakes. 

Seasoned the chicken with Garlic Powder prior to adding the broth. At the end pour the wet mixture into a bowl. Put back iin cooker. Chop green onions and add to chicken. Cover (can also add 2 or 3 green onions to broth while cooking. Will start to thicken and sauce will stick to chicken start by adding a tablespoon of butter to keep from sticking and to help sauce adhear and baste with sauce in bowl until ready to eat or cook off in oven for 15 min. Remember to baste so it seals in juices and doesnt dry out. I use breast and tenders along with thighs. You could use all cuts or a whole chicken too. Yummy. The honey helps ot adhear really well so you dont have to use the oven. Moist...keeper.

text:
I made a few tweaks to this after reading reviews and it was awesome. I used six thighs but kept the sauce the same.   I used low sodium soy sauce and cut the amount in half.  I used Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ sauce instead of ketchup.  I also added in one green bell pepper sliced.  Put it on high in my crock pot for 3 1/2 hours, took the chicken out of the sauce, added corn starch in to the sauce to thicken it and drizzled it over the chicken on the plates.  It was a huge success and everyone loved it.

I enjoyed the salt level in the recipe. My kids don't even eat dark meat and ate it. I added some of what others added to perfect it.  So I doubled all the sauce stuff ketshup soy sauce honey garlic and the herbs. I added pepper flakes brown sugar as well. After cooking I put chicken in oven for 30'min drizzled sauce over the top. I also used like 8 thighs and I cooked on high to get it done quicker. I served with chowmein noodles.  My noodles taste like panda. Good recipe. region:

country:
None
text:
Turned out pretty well. We used 1/3 cup of low sodium soy so, we can control the salt level. The skin and bones were removed from chicken thighs at the tail end of the cooking and the chicken was shredded & returned to the crock pot to absorb the sauce. We thinned the sauce out with 1/4 cup of apple juice to create more of a thin, saucey consistency. It was quite tasty with white rice. The key is to skim the fat off of the sauce before returning the chicken to the crock pot. We ommited the basil. This recipe is easy to tweak & prepare. Happy cooking!

As a full-time student and full-time single father, it truly is no wonder why a crock pot is a blessing. I made this recipe last night because I happened to already have everything on hand it called for and let it cook all day, with the pleasing aroma stoking my sister's and her husband's envy. I always try to follow the recipe without any modifications on the first attempt and this recipe, as is, was just as good, although next time I might add some crushed red pepper. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this a couple of times and I really like it. I modify it a little: I add a squirt of sriracha hot chili sauce to the mix. Crock pots differ, and I've found mine cooks this properly, on low, in about 4-and-one-half hours. I like to add a bunch of broccoli florets for the last half hour or so. I've made it with skin-on thighs, too, which makes quite a bit of liquid, which I mix with brown rice. Probably not great for the fat content, but I don't use it all, just a bit. I've also made it with skin-on chicken breasts, and it's good too, but you have to be careful not to overcook.

text:
A quick tip to elevate this recipe to a whole new level of deliciousness... Brown the thighs in a pan with 2 Tbsp oil over high heat for 2-3 minutes per side. Then add them to the crockpot and follow the recipe as written. I read several reviews and can't believe no one mentioned this easy tip! It adds so much flavor to the chicken and the sauce.

text:
It was really good! I deviated from the recipe a bit: I used 6 chicken thighs instead of 4, and added some cayenne for a little kick. I also defrosted my chicken before hand, so it was done cooking in 2 hours on low. It might take 4 hours if the chicken is frozen, it seems. I also reduced the amount of soy sauce and ketchup to 1/4 cup instead of 1/3 cup, and the saltiness level was perfect. I served it with some steamed broccoli and bread, and it was a hit for my dear boyfriend! I will made it again :)

userID:
11893681
Display Name:
peachyjo
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
8
favoritesCount:
3
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used four chicken thighs but cut back on the soy sauce and the ketchup, per other reviewers who stated it was "salty."  I certainly do not appreciate salty foods!

I used 1/3 cup soy sauce, 1/3 cup ketchup, 1/4 cup honey, 1 tsp dried basil but doubled the garlic (just because I love garlic).  It was still A LOT of sauce in the crock pot.

In the last 1.5 hours of cooking (on low), I added a whole cabbage (cut lengthwise-for presentation) into the crockpot and placed the cabbage on the bottom (so the cabbage would cook faster) and set the thighs on top of the cabbage.  There was still enough sauce to not allow the thighs to dry out.

Having read other reviewers, I opted to cook only about 4.5 hours on low and the thighs were definitely cooked, but not overcooked so they were not dry, unlike some of the other reviews.

The thighs (and my cabbage) had good flavor but I still did think it was on the "salty" side, which is why I had the idea of putting the cabbage into the crock pot (so it would soak the sauce up a bit and have some vegetable on the side to go with the chicken).  I also made cous cous which my kids love.  They ended up simply mixing the chicken with the cous cous and cabbage and it was perfectly tasty!

I will definitely make it again but will reduce the soy sauce, ketchup and honey even less next time.  Maybe I'll add some fingerling potatoes to serve on the side as well...

text:
1.  Used bone-in thighs (8) without changing glaze amount.
2.  Cooked on high for 3 hours
3.  Microwaved glaze for 1 minute before pouring over chicken.

I liked that I had the ingredients and that it was easy.  I left the skin on a couple of the thighs since this showed pictures with the skin.  I got home and realized that my slow cooker hadn't been plugged in, so had to cook them on high for 3 hours, and they were fine - totally cooked through.

What I didn't like is that, like so many slow cooker recipes, I ended up with chicken-thigh soup.  The meat ends up boiling vs. roasting.  I think if I made this again, I'd try it in the oven so that the glaze really sticks.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This recipe was OK, but nothing special.  I followed the recipe exactly the first time, but kept my eye on the chicken's temperature and the sauce's concentration.  As others have reported, the thighs were fully cooked after two hours and twenty minutes.  The sauce was thin but not watery, and I can see how it would become too salty if allowed to over concentrate.  I figured this was a case where the slow cooker just wasn't the right choice for this meal so I decided to give it another chance.  

I made it a second time, but this time I just used it as a guide to make a stir-fry.  I used boneless skinless chicken thighs and cut them into bite sized pieces.  For the sauce I replaced the ketchup with an equal amount of Sriracha, and added a little fresh grated ginger.  A quick stir-fry, a little cornstarch slurry to thicken, and I had a great honey sriracha chicken.  

I'll definitely keep the modified sauce around, but as for the recipe as written?  Not going to bother again.

country:
