text:
This has become a favourite recipe when I'm going to be out all afternoon.  I follow the ingredients as listed although I put in 1/4 tsp dried thyme, a lot more garlic and hot chili flakes.  I also use low sodium soy sauce to cut the salt down. 

Like many others, I buy boneless, skinless thighs (my new go-to protein).  I saute an onion first for a few minutes, add the garlic and cook for another minute or two.  Then I add 12-16 boneless & skinless chicken thighs (no change to sauce quantity - there is plenty) and brown them.  Then I pour everything in a slow cooker and simmer for 1.5 - 2  hours.   Serve with basmati rice and your choice of veggie.  My family loves this dish.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-05-29T18:00:26.543
helpfulCount:

text:
It was way too salty. To save this recipe, I would cut the soy in half, add tomato sauce along with the ketchup, add ginger and sesame, add a little more honey and a lot more garlic. I also followed someone's suggestion to then thicken the sauce with cornstarch over the stove and that was a good improvement. I would not make this recipe again unless I made some serious changes.

country:
None
text:
This was such an easy recipe and delivered great results.  I used boneless, skinless chicken thighs.  Next time, I believe the chicken thighs only need to be in the crockpot for 4.5 hours.  When the thighs have been cooked too long, they tend to taste a bit dry.
I also followed another reviewer's suggestion by taking the cooked chicken out of the crockpot and added some cornstarch to thicken the sauce.
I will definitely be making this recipe again.

It was delicious and made my house smell awesome! I used my nesco roaster oven on 350¬∞ for an hour and a half and it come out perfect! Nice n juicy! I did make a few changes. I used 1/4 cup ketchup 1/4 cup of soy sauce 1/2 cup of honey about 1/2 minced garlic. After about 45 minuets I added 2 tablespoons of corn starch mixed with two tablespoons of water to thicken the sauce. Came out awesome and my family loved it! Would definitely make it again!

userID:
1270564
Display Name:
KIMAYA24
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
6
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was very good and easy!  Didn't have soy sauce so I used a Soy Sauce Substitute recipe from this site (molasses, balsamic vinegar [didn't have balsamic so I used 5 parts regular vinegar to 1 part sugar], ginger,  garlic powder, & water).  Used 10 small boneless skinless chicken thighs.  Seasoned the chicken with sea salt, garlic powder, and pepper.  I was a little worried reading through reviews saying the dish was too salty after I already had it in the crockpot, but it was fine with my soy sauce substitute.  Also squeezed the juice of 1 orange while cooking and thickened the sauce on the stove with corn starch as others recommended.  Also added some oregano, rosemary, thyme, and garlic powder to the sauce.  As others stated, cooking time was actually around 4.5 - 5 hours on low.

Sprinkled with sesame seeds and served over Jasmine rice with roasted butternut squash and onions.  I really enjoyed it as did my husband and will definitely make it again!

5

text:
Simple I used 1/4 cup honey, 1/4 cup ketchup, 1/4 cup soy sauce low sodium. Stuck it in the oven at 365 degrees for 50 minutes, basking every 15 min. and then add addition 2-3 min on broil. Watch it because it burns fast! I also added a bit of ginger powder as well as red pepper flakes. cooked only 3 thighs, next time will make more when there is a sale.

text:
Overall very tasty, but I did make the following adjustments:
Added only 1/4 C of soy sauce
Used 8 boneless/skinless thighs
Added a bit of poultry seasoning and smoked the chicken for 1 hour first.  Then put in slow cooker for 4 1/2 hours on high.
Served with brown rice, snap peas and water chestnuts.  I also topped with finely chopped green onion before I served. The sauce is not thick, however it does give the chicken a great flavor.   We don't like a thick heavy sauce so this was perfect.  My sweetie and I have happy bellies!!

text:
Made it with some changes:

used 2 boneless breasts, two thighs and 4 small legs - we wanted leftovers.

Added 2 Tbsp of "Anything Sauce" (get this in Nashville, TN), 2 Tbsp of Wasabi - we like spicy dishes.  Used pre-minced garlic. Everything else was the same in the recipe.

Cooked on high for 4 hrs, low for 1 hr.   Chicken was very tender, fall off the bone, moist.  My hubby loved it and so did I.  Will make it again!  Thanks for a great recipe!

Display Name:
Sally

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I did not care much for the flavor of these thighs, too much soy.  My husband likes soy and he did not eat these very enthusiastically for all that.  I did use lo Na soy but used the recommended amount.  The thighs were overcooked.  I used six thighs as recommended by others.  Maybe it would have been better with only four thighs.  I did thicken the sauce with the cornstarch slurry as suggested by some.  Perhaps the type of honey might make a difference.  There are so many kinds of honey and I have found they have distinctly different flavors.  That stuff you buy off the shelf is not very good quality honey.  I used an orange blossom honey thinking that would go great with the chicken and soy but maybe I should have used something stronger!
Review:
Rating:
1
dateLastModified:
2016-01-31T16:38:20.54

userID:
1553296
Display Name:
Karen Martin
isPro:
False
followersCount:
10
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
141
favoritesCount:
400
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/190.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious and very easy.  I used chicken breasts because my thighs spent one too many days in the fridge and were bad when I went to use them.  I ended up sung a 3 pack of breasts that was about 2.4 pounds, and I cut them in half.  I think the sauce was enough for even more chicken if you have a big family.  I would go as far as 3 pounds.  I whisked together the sauce the night before and put it all in a big ziplock with the chicken in the fridge overnight.  I didn't think it needed the full 6 hours but use your judgement.  The sauce thinned out in the crock (no surprise, everything in the crock gets watery from condensation).  I ladled out a little of the watery sauce into a saucepan and boiled it on the stove to thicken it, but I don't think that was necessary.  Even though the sauce was thin, I think it was an ok consistency to pour over the finished chicken served over rice.  

Next time I make this, I may add just a little shake of red pepper flakes to give it some heat.  It was pretty sweet, but my kids and my husband loved it.  I just put a squirt of sriracha on my serving and it was fine like that.
Review:
Rating:
3
dateLastModified:
2016-01-13T18:29:58.837
helpfulCount:
0

This was "good". I followed the recipe.  I'll keep it as it was real easy but if something better comes along, I'll discard it. I tried this again but baked it in the oven and liked it much better. I felt the crock-pot method watered down the sauce too much. It is a nice tasting sauce if done in the oven and it doesn't get watered down.  I put a double layer of foil on the pan I used to bake it in.

I LOVED this recipe!! It came out SO good. My entire family enjoyed the meal and I can say that we will be making it again. It didn't take very long to prepare, the ingredients weren't too complex, and their wasn't a huge mess to clean up after. region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tasty and easy. I used approx double the quantities given and it fed us for lunch the next day too. Gives a sweet brown sauce, almost with a hoi-sin vibe, and the chicken is moist and tender. The sauce goes in the pan as a thick glaze, but comes out very runny when hot,  so you could stir in some cornflour at the end for a thicker sauce. Use a low-salt soy sauce to avoid it getting too salty. I only needed to put it on low for 4.5 - 5 hours or so, I think the 6 hours stated would have overcooked it.

region:

country:
None
text:
The whole family really enjoyed  this dish! e have a large household so I doubled the recipe for the sauce and used about 16 pieces of bone-in, skin on chicken thighs (that's what was on hand). Changes made were using more chicken and using half soy sauce and half aminos for a lower salt content.  Since we used skin on chicken, about 20 minutes before serving I put the chicken on a baking tray, added a lil cornstarch and water mixture into the sauce to thicken it some, drizzled it over the chicken and put it in the oven at 400 degree's to crisp up the skin. Came out looking just like the picture! The guys all used the sauce with their rice as well.  I will definitely be making it again. (Served it with steamed broccoli and cauliflower)

I made couple changes as suggested in some of reviews. 1. Lessen the soy sauce to 1/4 cup instead of the 1/2 cup in the recipe. WHAT A MISTAKE!   It s now too sweet . I don't get why so many said it s too salty. The honey should balance it off. 2. I added cornstarch to thicken the sauce. I really didn't see the sauce thicken much.
4 stars because the meat came out tough and too much fat using chicken thighs. 
Mine came out like in the picture and I am very bad at cooking.  I wouldn't change anything  in the recipe at all.  If you want to use more chicken thights, there s no need to double the ingredients for sauce.

text:
Amazingly delicious! It was definitely overcooked with a 6 hour cook time on low so I'll adjust that next time for sure. 
I was a bit skeptical about the spice choice but tried it as written other than the amount of soy sauce and it went well. I used 1/4 of the amount of soy sauce called for because of the other reviews and I'm seriously glad that I did. I used 6 chicken leg quarters cleaned and skinned to lower the fat and have a more economical meal. Because it was falling off of the bone, I went with the flow and just deboned it and just made sandwiches for lunch with a whole grain bread and added light miracle whip. Yum! 
I'll make this again for sandwiches and save on the deli meat chicken prices. This recipe tasted fantastic, was economical, and had ingredients I usual have in my cupboard instead of exotic or unusual ones. I'll try it over rice with some veggies for dinner sometime as well. Very versatile recipe. Thanks for posting it.
Review:

userID:
9307848
Display Name:
Tivona
isPro:

0
madeRecipesCount:
7
favoritesCount:
2

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe. Its so good. I did do things a bit differently though. The recipe (as written) looked to sweet, to salty, and a bit low on garlic. Here is what I did and it was perfect. 

I reduced the honey to 2 tbsps plus 2 tsps. I upped the garlic to 6 cloves. I also added about 1/8 tsp of 5 spice seasoning. I used low sodium soy sauce the first time and just reduced the amount of soy sauce down to a 1/3 cup the second time. Both adjustments worked great.  I switched out the chicken for skinless goose breast the first time I made it and then skinless duck the next time I made it. Both the duck and goose were wonderful. Also I just want to say that the duck I did in a clay pot cooker. Soaked the clay pot and lid then popped it in the cold oven and set to 400. It took longer then I expected but turned out so great. The last 15 to 20 minutes I removed the lid and basted with the glaze drippings in the pot. Absolutely going to be making this again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
this was a great base recipe to play around with so that it suits your tastes. I made the following changes after reading some of the reviews: 

-- spread a diced white  onion in the bottom of the slow cooker before the chicken. 
-- used 6 boneless, skinless chicken breasts. 
-- for the sauce: 1/3 cup honey, 1/3 cup low sodium gluten free soy sauce, 1/3 cup ketchup, 6 cloves chopped garlic, freshly grated ginger, few teaspoons of brown sugar, 2 tsp dried basil, 1 tsp garlic powder, 1/2 tsp red pepper flakes
-- cooked on low for 4 hours
-- after cooking, removed chicken and added a cornstarch slurry to the sauce to thicken (maybe 1 tsp cornstarch dissolved in a big splash of water).

served everything over brown rice, with roasted broccoli on the side.

Good! However, I'm one of those who made adjustments.  Only used 1/4 cup of both low salt soy sauce and BBQ sauce (instead of ketchup). I did add about  2 tsp brown sugar. I actually baked it in a 350 degree oven for 15 minutes, turned, then baked another 20 minutes. I poured off the very runny sauce and added a little corn starch and heated it in the microwave (I was hungry and in a hurry!), stirring well till it thickened, then spread it over the chicken. Tasty!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was glad I read all your reviews and made these adjustments. A lot of people said it was too salty and dry so I used half of the soy sauce  recommendation , half the ketchup, added 1/2 cup dark brown sugar, prolly 1 1/2 tablespoons of chili pepper flakes, and added a cup of water. I used 9 in bone with skin chicken thighs and didn't double the sauce. Their was plenty of sauce leftover. After cooking in my croc pot for 3 hours on low I had my husband put on warm until I got home about 4 hours later. Next time I will have him just take the chicken out because it was a lil dry but I added some of the sauce after I added some flour and water to thicken the sauce in a sauce pan and it was good. Sauce was good enough to add to the white rice. I also broiled the chicken for a few mins to give it that crispy flavor and look. I served it with white rice and steamed carrots and my family loved it. I have a picky husband too and was happy to see everyone's plate cleaned.  I will make again and like I said the only adjustment I would do is take the chicken out of the crockpot instead of letting it sit on warm for a while.

This was  good. I followed the recipe with the exception of using reduced sodium soy sauce, chicken breasts, and garlic powder as these were the ingredients I had on hand. I served it over rice. It is even better over quinoa.  I put the chicken breasts in frozen and thickened the sauce/shredded the chicken towards the end.  The last time I made it I added mushrooms and 1/2 an onion. It was yummy. Easy and filling.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1619871.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ive made it several times. Ive tweeked it and came up with the following. I like to remove the skin and leave bone in. I use equal parts Soy, Bbq, Hoison, Ketchup, and Honey to equal 1 2/3 cups liquid. Added more garlic and some chili pepper flakes. Left on low for 4 1/2 hours then removed from slow cooker and broiled in oven to caramelise the sauce. While they were in oven I added a bit of cornstarch to remaining sauce and put cooker on high. Placed chicken on a bed of coconut rice anf drizzled sauce over finished product. Great recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had a bigger crock pot and just got some chicken thighs with bone, so I piled in 12 of them with skin removed.  I did not double the quantity of liquid, but there was still quite a bit at the end of cooking.

I prepared the chicken in the evening and allowed it to sit in the liquid (in fridge) overnight.  In the afternoon, about 5 hours prior to dinner my wife turned it on.

I followed the advice of some and used low sodium soy sauce.   The chicken was not salty at all, in fact it kinda lacked some taste.  It was just quite bland.

I followed some recommendations to thicken the sauce with some corn starch, put some over the chicken (I still had quit a bit left), and broil the chicken it for a bit.  The color did get a bit nicer, but the taste was still quite bland.

text:
I have made this with both chicken thighs and drumsticks several times each, and it is always amazing. Suggested changes for those who like it sweeter: instead of 1/2 cup of ketchup, use 1/4 cup of each ketchup and BBQ sauce, and add 2-3 Tbsp of brown sugar. Using low-sodium soy sauce doesn't hurt, either. Goes great with either mashed potatoes or rice.

text:
Excellent recipe, and I made it exactly as per the recipe except for one thing...which was doubling the number of chicken thigh pieces (skinless but bone in because I was too lazy to bone it). My 2 year old gobbled it up. A couple of reviewers thought it was too salty, and this might be because they used light soy which has higher sodium content than dark soy sauce. Also, I haven't tried it yet, but it would work to cut the soy sauce to a 1/3 cup instead of using a full 1/2c if people are worried about their salt intake.

text:
First rule - never use a slow cooker while you are still in the house...  the divine smells will drive you crazy!  When first put together the taste of the sauce was perfect. Unfortunately, as reviewer Brian discovered, with the slow cooking the salt became predominant and rather ruined the end results. I used 1/4 c low sodium soya s and 1/4 regular soya.  This sauce replicates VH's Honey Garlic Sauce, which I love, so am ecstatic to have found a recipe from scratch. Will definitely be making again but either not in a slow cooker or adjusting the soy somehow - what a shame as this is a marvelous recipe!
I had also added 2 legs and all had skin & bones - and some were even still partially frozen but no problem - 4 hours on high - they were fall off the bone!  Thank you Myrna!

text:
After reading the reviews, I decided to make this in the oven because I wanted a sticky type chicken without having to thicken the sauce.  I only used one-half the amount of soy sauce.  I baked my chicken first to about 145 degrees and then siphoned off the juice.  I poured and basted the chicken with the sauce and continued cooking until the meat fell off the bone! It was the best ever!  I served this to approximately 50 homeless shelter residents and they are now my best friends! I would definitely make this again!

text:
I have made this dish twice this week. It is super easy and a huge hit in my household.  I ran out of soy sauce and substituted 3/4 cup of bottled teriyaki sauce marinade (there are a number of varieties in the grocery store). It was thicker than the soy sauce so it made a nice, thick sauce without extra steps.  I also increased the garlic by about one third and could easily put in more without it being too garlicky. Cooked for 6 hours on low and it was fork tender.  This will be one of my go-to weeknight dishes.

text:
This was great. It is naturally gluten free as long as you use g/f soy sauce, so I really liked that about the recipe. I did substitute one can of diced tomatoes with garlic and basil for 1/2 of the ketchup. That seemed like a lot of sweetness with the honey and ketchup. By using the flavored tomatoes it didn't water it down. It was perfect. I served it over rice, and my husband added his mandatory red pepper flakes, and we were both happy. Great for leftovers too.

I made a few changes based on what I had in my pantry and a little bit of inspiration. I didn't have fresh garlic or straight basil, so I used garlic powder and Italian Seasoning. I also added some ginger and tinkered with the proportions ‚Äì ‚Äì I ended up adding a little more ketchup and honey, if I recall correctly. After the thighs were cooked, I removed them and added some cornstarch to thicken it up. about 10 minutes before serving, I added the chicken back in along with some slightly undercooked broccoli and turned the crockpot off. I it served over jasmine rice and called it "Vaguely Asian Chicken", LOL. Everyone liked it, and it's a tough crowd at my house ‚Äì ‚Äì a toddler, a kindergartner, and a 40-year-old man who are all very picky. ;-) I will keep tinkering with it and probably change it up a little bit every time I make it. I am making it again tonight and I am adding some toasted sesame seeds and serving it with string beans. I love that it is a versatile recipe using pantry staples!

text:
This is really easy and Very tasty!  I changed a couple of things for personal health reasons.  First I doubled the recipe since I had 10 thighs.   I used 1/2 cup low sodium soy sauce, and 1 1/2 cups water, 1/3 cup honey and 1/3 cup agave nectar.  it was really good, and the chicken was falling apart it was so tender.  Next time the only change I will make other than those listed here.  Is to cut the basil back just a bit. It was a bit strong for me.  Thank you for sharing your recipe it made a really nice EASY dinner for us tonight.

text:
Mixed reviews on this recipe between my husband and me. He would give this recipe a 5; I give it a 2. My reason for a 2 is the very salty soy sauce taste; I am not a big soy sauce fan, while he is. It had too much soy sauce taste for me. I loved the ease of making it! The house smelled great as it cooked. I did not have chicken thighs and used breast meat; I do think it would have been better with thighs as it did not have that 'melt in your mouth' consistency with breast meat. We had it with white rice. I gave some of my chicken to my husband and then mixed the sauce still left into the rice and it cut down on the soy sauce flavor a lot for me. I would probably make this again since my husband really liked it.

I made this yesterday, and it was a hit with the whole family!!  I disagree with those who have commented that it was too salty, and I even used the recommended amount of Soy Sauce.  I made two small additions to the recipe:  I added 1 small diced onion, and about 1/3 Cup of Sriracha Chili Sauce to add a little zip to the sauce.  The Sriracha gave it a nice Spicey/Sweet contrast, and it was not too spicy.  I was also impressed by how easy this recipe is! I will definitely make this again!!  :)

text:
This was delicious! Much better than I expected and so quick to make. I followed the recipe pretty much, except I used boned thighs and drumsticks since that's what I had, and added more honey since I thought it would balance out the salty soy sauce out more. Also, I used light soy sauce. I cooked for just 5.5 hours and it was falling off the bone. The sauce was a bit thin to start, so I added some corn flour and it went into a lovely, sticky sauce! I had it with some basmati and it was a lovely meal! Definitely recommend this :)

It uses ingredients that everyone should already have, and it was simple to make.  More importantly, it tasked great.  My whole family (2 adults and two young kids) loved it.  I doubled the whole recipe - chicken and other ingredients.  This one will be a family staple.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is fabulous!! There are only a few pieces of advice I would offer. Firstly, save your money & use bone-in thighs. The meat is so tender, it will fall right off the bone. I remove the skins, as I don't like that much added fat. I cooked at least 8 thighs using this amount of sauce. Once the chicken is cooked, I remove the chicken & thicken the sauce with a tablespoon of corn starch & water. Serve it over rice or with noodles. Plus, we keep any left over sauce & use it later in the week for a stir fry.

text:
Delicious! But I do have to admit that I didn't cook this in the slow cooker. I had the intentions to but time passed too quickly so I followed everything to the letter and popped it all into a Pyrex dish with Pyrex glass lid and cooked in the oven for 1hr10, took the lid off then cooked for a further 15-20mins at 180c (fan) while the rice was cooking.. It was yummy and even my son who is an extremely picky eater ate the lot and asked for more... Oh and I used low sodium soy sauce and the salt level in this meal was spot on!

Next time I make it I will add some chilli to please my fianc√© who loves spicy food.
